channel.title: Ars-Technica on Panz3r News
channel.description: Recent content in Ars-Technica on news.panz3r.dev

item.title: Invincible S1: Clearly TV’s most fun superhero shows are on Amazon these days
item.description: Not even Smallville could combine YA drama and superhero DNA this well.

item.title: Will Virgin Galactic ever be successful? A new book provides insights
item.description: “It’s hard to make decisions around here sometimes.”

item.title: Why are game-makers creating new Game Boy games in 2021?
item.description: New tools and wide-eyed nostalgia are driving a monochrome portable renaissance.

item.title: How one naughty bird cheats with fancy feather structures
item.description: Male tanager birds have more than one way to make their colors really pop for the ladies.

item.title: Four astronauts make first nighttime landing in the ocean since 1968
item.description: “I would just like to say, quite frankly, y’all are changing the world.”

item.title: White House says Vice President Kamala Harris will chair the Space Council
item.description: “I think her approach to this is just going to be to get the job done.”

item.title: What became of 2009’s Left 4 Dead 2 boycott? Here’s the inside story
item.description: In gaming since L4D2, fan campaigns have even pressured devs to release entirely new endings.

item.title: An ambitious plan to tackle ransomware faces long odds
item.description: Heavyweight task force proposes framework to tackle a major cybersecurity problem.

item.title: Ford’s ever-smarter robots are speeding up the assembly line
item.description: A transmission factory shows how AI may gradually creep into industrial processes

item.title: Disney gets special “theme park” exception to Florida’s anti-tech bill
item.description: A legal challenge to the new law seems inevitable.

item.title: More US agencies potentially hacked, this time with Pulse Secure exploits
item.description: Zeroday vulnerability under attack has a severity rating of 10 out of 10.

item.title: Mysterious health attacks like those seen in Cuba have come to DC
item.description: US security official was reportedly sickened outside the White House last year.

item.title: The NYPD retires “Digidog” robot after public backlash
item.description: Dystopian robot dogs will no longer be patrolling the mean streets of NYC.

item.title: New York requires $15 broadband for poor people, promptly gets sued by ISPs
item.description: Lobby groups for Verizon, AT�T, and other ISPs ask court to overturn state law.

item.title: Porsche rumored to be entering F1 with Red Bull Racing
item.description: Rumors of Porsche in F1 never go away, and a rival team boss thinks it’s happening.

item.title: Climate law jeopardizes freedoms, German court rules—but not how you think
item.description: Don’t punt on emissions reductions after 2030, top court said.

item.title: Roku vs. Google, part 2: YouTube TV app pulled from Roku Store
item.description: Google wants AV1 support for lower bandwidth costs, Roku says that’s too expensive.

item.title: Humble Bundle creator brings antitrust lawsuit against Valve over Steam
item.description: “At bottom, Valve’s scheme imposes a massive tax on the PC Desktop Gaming industry.”

item.title: New iPad Pro, Apple TV 4K, and 24-inch iMac now available for order
item.description: Most are shipping May 21, but the 12.9-inch iPad Pro has slipped several weeks.

item.title: EU says Apple’s 30% cut from rival music providers violates competition law
item.description: EU sides with Spotify, blasts Apple’s 30% App Store cut and anti-steering rules.

item.title: SpaceX cancels Starship flight attempt on Friday [Updated]
item.description: After four landing failures, here’s hoping the fifth time is the charm.

item.title: Dozens of viruses seem to use a different DNA base
item.description: Odd form of DNA helps viruses resist their host’s defenses.

item.title: What I learned about cars watching all 8 Fast & Furious movies in 4 days
item.description: Revisiting our 2019 marathon of vehicular wisdom, thanks to new theatrical promotion.

item.title: Rocket Report: Blue Origin protests Starship, China launches space station
item.description: “The ability to refuel in space is critical to meeting NASA’s goals."

item.title: Does nuclear secrecy make us secure? New book offers counterargument
item.description: Historian Alex Wellerstein: “You could get rid of all the secrecy tomorrow and the world would not measurably become more dangerous.”

item.title: Leaks: May 21 will be the launch day for the new iMac, iPad Pro, and Apple TV
item.description: A prominent leaker, a UK retailer, and Apple itself all let the date slip.

item.title: Uber, Lyft stocks plunge after Biden official says drivers are employees
item.description: Uber and Lyft argue treating drivers as employees would wreck their business.

item.title: Today’s best deals: Lots of video games, rechargeable batteries, and more
item.description: Dealmaster also has deals on Fitbit trackers and noise-canceling headphones.

item.title: FCC reveals sign-up date and website for $50-per-month broadband subsidies
item.description: May 12 enrollment for people who have low incomes or lost income during pandemic.

item.title: A Chinese company has started charging for fully driverless rides
item.description: China has the world’s strongest self-driving industry after the United States.

item.title: Brazil rejects Sputnik V vaccine, says it’s tainted with replicating cold virus
item.description: Adenovirus-vector vaccines are supposed to be engineered so they can’t replicate.

item.title: Microsoft follows Epic’s lead, lowers its cut of PC game sales to 12%
item.description: But the move may not be enough to dislodge heavily entrenched competition.

item.title: Conspiracy theorist said death threats were “jokes”—but jury didn’t buy it
item.description: Brendan Hunt posted videos about murdering US elected officials.

item.title: Want to save an island’s coral reefs? Get rid of invasive rats
item.description: Rats drive off birds, setting off a cascade of ecosystem damages that spread offshore.

item.title: Verizon tries to sell Yahoo and AOL after spending $9 billion on fallen giants
item.description: After spending $9 billion combined, Verizon may sell units for $4 billion or so.

item.title: You can now teach the Google Assistant how to pronounce names
item.description: Google can listen to you pronounce a name and learn from it.

item.title: Gas prices are expected to rise due to the truck driver shortage
item.description: Robotrucks aren’t here to save us yet.

item.title: Returnal review: Roguelite arcade combat has never felt this epic—or hard [Updated]
item.description: Legendary dev Housemarque nails its most ambitious game yet, but beware its pitfalls.

item.title: This is the slightly sportier, slightly more efficient 2022 Honda Civic
item.description: The next Civic looks less like a starfighter, inside and out.

item.title: Facing uncharted waters, Apple reports 54% year-over-year revenue increase
item.description: Chip shortages and a waning pandemic might make growth unsustainable, though.

item.title: Office default Calibri will join Clippy, Internet Explorer in Windows retirement
item.description: “Calibri in Office” could almost drive (15 years old), but a new sans serif will soon emerge.

item.title: Verizon “leads” all US carriers in mmWave 5G availability at 0.8%
item.description: Phones capable of using mmWave 5G access it less than 1% of the time.

item.title: Algorithms were under fire at a Senate hearing on social media
item.description: “Algorithms have great potential for good. They can also be misused.”

item.title: Chipmaker says it will ramp up production of older 28nm chips
item.description: Fourth-largest contract chipmaker aiming at supply problems for carmakers, others.

item.title: Michael Collins, who piloted the Apollo 11 command module, has died
item.description: “The nation lost a true pioneer and lifelong advocate for exploration.”

item.title: Epic deposition shows how differently Google and Apple treat messaging
item.description: Apple considered fighting a Google/WhatsApp acquisition with iMessage on Android.

item.title: Play this Dreamcast Castlevania game 20+ years after it was canceled
item.description: Castlevania: Resurrection was briefly seen at E3 1999, then vanished for decades.

item.title: Toyota is entering a hydrogen-powered Corolla in a 24-hour race
item.description: It’s still internal combustion, not a fuel cell.

item.title: SitRep: Is the F-35 officially a failure?
item.description: Cost overruns, other issues prompt Air Force to look for “clean sheet” fighter.

item.title: These concept interiors for an electric Lexus are thought-provoking
item.description: Untreated leather, translucent silicone cushions, and granite steering wheels.

item.title: New Pokémon Snap is a welcome take on the “first-person shooter”
item.description: Plenty of secrets and adorable moments make for the perfect relaxation game.

item.title: Ransomware crooks threaten to ID informants if cops don’t pay up
item.description: The FBI is investigating claim hackers obtained 250GB of police department data.

item.title: Nestlé threatened with cease-and-desist over alleged illegal water use
item.description: Company’s claims hinge on how much water early-1900s rail cars carried.

item.title: High-bandwidth wireless BCI demonstrated in humans for first time
item.description: BrainGate device complements Neuralink’s successful test of wireless BCI in monkey.
